sn48.10:1.3.eng: The faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

sn48.10:1.4.eng: And what is the faculty of faith?

sn48.10:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako saddho hoti, saddahati tathāgatassa bodhiṃ:
sn48.10:1.5.eng: It’s when a noble disciple has faith in the Realized One’s awakening:

sn48.10:1.6.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti—
sn48.10:1.6.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

sn48.10:1.7.eng: This is called the faculty of faith.

sn48.10:2.1.eng: And what is the faculty of energy?

sn48.10:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako āraddhavīriyo viharati akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya, kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ upasampadāya, thāmavā daḷhaparakkamo anikkhittadhuro kusalesu dhammesu.
sn48.10:2.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple lives with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They’re strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.

sn48.10:2.3.pli: So anuppannānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ anuppādāya chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati;
sn48.10:2.3.eng: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that bad, unskillful qualities don’t arise.

sn48.10:2.4.pli: uppannānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati;
sn48.10:2.4.eng: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen are given up.

sn48.10:2.5.pli: anuppannānaṃ kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ uppādāya chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati;
sn48.10:2.5.eng: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities arise.

sn48.10:2.6.pli: uppannānaṃ kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ ṭhitiyā asammosāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati—
sn48.10:2.6.eng: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities that have arisen remain, are not lost, but increase, mature, and are completed by development.

sn48.10:2.7.eng: This is called the faculty of energy.

sn48.10:3.1.eng: And what is the faculty of mindfulness?

sn48.10:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako satimā hoti paramena satinepakkena samannāgato, cirakatampi cirabhāsitampi saritā anussaritā.
sn48.10:3.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple is mindful. They have utmost mindfulness and alertness, and can remember and recall what was said and done long ago.

sn48.10:3.3.pli: So kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn48.10:3.3.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn48.10:3.4.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn48.10:3.6.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ—
sn48.10:3.6.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn48.10:3.7.eng: This is called the faculty of mindfulness.

sn48.10:4.1.eng: And what is the faculty of immersion?

sn48.10:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako vossaggārammaṇaṃ karitvā labhati samādhiṃ, labhati cittassa ekaggataṃ.
sn48.10:4.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple, relying on letting go, gains immersion, gains unification of mind.

sn48.10:4.3.pli: So vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
sn48.10:4.3.eng: Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

sn48.10:4.4.pli: Vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
sn48.10:4.4.eng: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.

sn48.10:4.5.pli: Pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sato ca sampajāno sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedeti yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
sn48.10:4.5.eng: And with the fading away of rapture, they enter and remain in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’

sn48.10:4.6.pli: Sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati—
sn48.10:4.6.eng: With the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

sn48.10:4.7.eng: This is called the faculty of immersion.

sn48.10:5.1.eng: And what is the faculty of wisdom?

sn48.10:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako paññavā hoti udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya, sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā.
sn48.10:5.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.

sn48.10:5.3.pli: So ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti—
sn48.10:5.3.eng: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

sn48.10:5.4.eng: This is called the faculty of wisdom.

sn48.11:1.3.eng: The faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

sn48.11:1.4.eng: And what is the faculty of faith?

sn48.11:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako saddho hoti, saddahati tathāgatassa bodhiṃ:
sn48.11:1.5.eng: It’s when a noble disciple has faith in the Realized One’s awakening:

sn48.11:1.6.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti—
sn48.11:1.6.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

sn48.11:1.7.eng: This is called the faculty of faith.

sn48.11:2.1.eng: And what is the faculty of energy?

sn48.11:2.2.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhave, cattāro sammappadhāne ārabbha vīriyaṃ paṭilabhati—
sn48.11:2.2.eng: The energy that’s gained in connection with the four right efforts.

sn48.11:2.3.eng: This is called the faculty of energy.

sn48.11:3.1.eng: And what is the faculty of mindfulness?

sn48.11:3.2.pli: Yaṃ kho, bhikkhave, cattāro satipaṭṭhāne ārabbha satiṃ paṭilabhati—
sn48.11:3.2.eng: The mindfulness that’s gained in connection with the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

sn48.11:3.3.eng: This is called the faculty of mindfulness.

sn48.11:4.1.eng: And what is the faculty of immersion?

sn48.11:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako vossaggārammaṇaṃ karitvā labhati samādhiṃ, labhati cittassa ekaggataṃ—
sn48.11:4.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple, relying on letting go, gains immersion, gains unification of mind.

sn48.11:4.3.eng: This is called the faculty of immersion.

sn48.11:5.1.eng: And what is the faculty of wisdom?

sn48.11:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako paññavā hoti udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā—
sn48.11:5.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.

sn48.11:5.3.eng: This is called the faculty of wisdom.

sn48.115-124:1.3.eng: Desire for rebirth in the realm of luminous form, desire for rebirth in the formless realm, conceit, restlessness, and ignorance.

sn48.115-124:1.4.eng: These are the five higher fetters.

sn48.115-124:1.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ uddhambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya pañcindriyāni bhāvetabbāni.
sn48.115-124:1.5.eng: The five faculties should be developed for the direct knowledge, complete understanding, finishing, and giving up of these five higher fetters.

sn48.115-124:1.7.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu saddhindriyaṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ …pe… paññindriyaṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ.
sn48.115-124:1.7.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops the faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom, which rely on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripen as letting go.

sn48.115-124:1.8.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ uddhambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya imāni pañcindriyāni bhāvetabbānī”ti.
sn48.115-124:1.8.eng: These five faculties should be developed for the direct knowledge, complete understanding, finishing, and giving up of these five higher fetters.”

sn48.115-124:1.10.eng: (Tell in full as in the Linked Discourses on the Path, SN 45.171–179, with the above as the final discourse.)

sn48.12:1.3.eng: The faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

sn48.12:1.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ samattā paripūrattā arahaṃ hoti, tato mudutarehi anāgāmī hoti, tato mudutarehi sakadāgāmī hoti, tato mudutarehi sotāpanno hoti, tato mudutarehi dhammānusārī hoti, tato mudutarehi saddhānusārī hotī”ti.
sn48.12:1.5.eng: Someone who has completed and fulfilled these five faculties is a perfected one. If they are weaker than that, they’re a non-returner. If they are weaker still, they’re a once-returner. If they are weaker still, they’re a stream-enterer. If they’re weaker still, they’re a follower of teachings. If they’re weaker still, they’re a follower by faith.”

sn48.125-136:0.2.eng: 13. Another Chapter of Abbreviated Texts on the Ganges

sn48.125-136:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, gaṅgā nadī pācīnaninnā pācīnapoṇā pācīnapabbhārā;
sn48.125-136:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, the Ganges river slants, slopes, and inclines to the east.

sn48.125-136:1.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu pañcindriyāni bhāvento pañcindriyāni bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro.
sn48.125-136:1.2.eng: In the same way, a mendicant developing and cultivating the five faculties slants, slopes, and inclines to extinguishment.

sn48.125-136:1.3.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu pañcindriyāni bhāvento pañcindriyāni bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro?

sn48.125-136:1.4.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu saddhindriyaṃ bhāveti rāgavinayapariyosānaṃ dosavinayapariyosānaṃ mohavinayapariyosānaṃ …pe… paññindriyaṃ bhāveti rāgavinayapariyosānaṃ dosavinayapariyosānaṃ mohavinayapariyosānaṃ.
sn48.125-136:1.4.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops the faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom, which culminate in the removal of greed, hate, and delusion.

sn48.125-136:1.5.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu pañcindriyāni bhāvento pañcindriyāni bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro”ti.
sn48.125-136:1.5.eng: That’s how a mendicant developing and cultivating the five faculties slants, slopes, and inclines to extinguishment.”

sn48.125-136:2.1.eng: Six on slanting to the east,

sn48.125-136:2.2.eng: and six on slanting to the ocean;

sn48.125-136:2.4.eng: and that’s how this chapter is recited.

sn48.13:1.3.eng: The faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

sn48.13:1.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ samattā paripūrattā arahaṃ hoti, tato mudutarehi anāgāmī hoti, tato mudutarehi sakadāgāmī hoti, tato mudutarehi sotāpanno hoti, tato mudutarehi dhammānusārī hoti, tato mudutarehi saddhānusārī hoti.
sn48.13:1.5.eng: Someone who has completed and fulfilled these five faculties is a perfected one. If they are weaker than that, they’re a non-returner … a once-returner … a stream-enterer … a follower of teachings … a follower by faith.

sn48.13:1.6.pli: Iti kho, bhikkhave, indriyavemattatā phalavemattatā hoti, phalavemattatā puggalavemattatā”ti.
sn48.13:1.6.eng: So from a disparity of faculties there’s a disparity of fruits. And from a disparity of fruits there’s a disparity of individuals.”

sn48.14:1.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ samattā paripūrattā arahaṃ hoti, tato mudutarehi anāgāmī hoti, tato mudutarehi sakadāgāmī hoti, tato mudutarehi sotāpanno hoti, tato mudutarehi dhammānusārī hoti, tato mudutarehi saddhānusārī hoti.
sn48.14:1.5.eng: Someone who has completed and fulfilled these five faculties is a perfected one. If they are weaker than that, they’re a non-returner … a once-returner … a stream-enterer … a follower of teachings … a follower by faith.

sn48.14:1.6.pli: Iti kho, bhikkhave, paripūraṃ paripūrakārī ārādheti, padesaṃ padesakārī ārādheti.
sn48.14:1.6.eng: So, mendicants, if you practice partially you succeed partially. If you practice fully you succeed fully.

sn48.14:1.7.eng: But in any case, these five faculties are not a waste, I say.”

sn48.18:1.3.eng: The faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

sn48.18:1.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ samattā paripūrattā arahaṃ hoti, tato mudutarehi arahattaphalasacchikiriyāya paṭipanno hoti, tato mudutarehi anāgāmī hoti, tato mudutarehi anāgāmiphalasacchikiriyāya paṭipanno hoti, tato mudutarehi sakadāgāmī hoti, tato mudutarehi sakadāgāmiphalasacchikiriyāya paṭipanno hoti, tato mudutarehi sotāpanno hoti, tato mudutarehi sotāpattiphalasacchikiriyāya paṭipanno hoti.
sn48.18:1.5.eng: Someone who has completed and fulfilled these five faculties is a perfected one. If they are weaker than that, they’re practicing to realize the fruit of perfection … a non-returner … practicing to realize the fruit of non-return … a once-returner … practicing to realize the fruit of once-return … a stream-enterer … practicing to realize the fruit of stream-entry.

sn48.18:1.6.pli: Yassa kho, bhikkhave, imāni pañcindriyāni sabbena sabbaṃ sabbathā sabbaṃ natthi, tamahaṃ ‘bāhiro puthujjanapakkhe ṭhito’ti vadāmī”ti.
sn48.18:1.6.eng: Someone who totally and utterly lacks these five faculties is an outsider who belongs with the ordinary persons, I say.”

sn48.19:1.1.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn48.19:1.1.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn48.19:2.1.eng: “Sir, they speak of someone who is ‘accomplished in the faculties’.

sn48.19:2.2.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, indriyasampanno hotī”ti?
sn48.19:2.2.eng: How is someone accomplished in the faculties defined?”

sn48.19:2.3.pli: “Idha, bhikkhu, bhikkhu saddhindriyaṃ bhāveti upasamagāmiṃ sambodhagāmiṃ, vīriyindriyaṃ bhāveti upasamagāmiṃ sambodhagāmiṃ, satindriyaṃ bhāveti upasamagāmiṃ sambodhagāmiṃ, samādhindriyaṃ bhāveti upasamagāmiṃ sambodhagāmiṃ, paññindriyaṃ bhāveti upasamagāmiṃ sambodhagāmiṃ.
sn48.19:2.3.eng: “Mendicant, it’s when a mendicant develops the faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom that lead to peace and awakening.

sn48.19:2.4.pli: Ettāvatā kho, bhikkhu, bhikkhu indriyasampanno hotī”ti.
sn48.19:2.4.eng: This is how someone who is accomplished in the faculties is defined.”

sn48.2:1.3.eng: The faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

sn48.2:1.4.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako imesaṃ pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti—
sn48.2:1.4.eng: A noble disciple comes to truly understand these five faculties’ gratification, drawback, and escape.

sn48.2:1.5.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako sotāpanno avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo”ti.
sn48.2:1.5.eng: Such a noble disciple is called a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.”

sn48.20:1.3.eng: The faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

sn48.20:1.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā bhikkhu āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharatī”ti.
sn48.20:1.5.eng: It’s because of developing and cultivating these five faculties that a mendicant realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.”

sn48.21:1.3.eng: The faculties of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

sn48.21:1.4.pli: Yāvakīvañcāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imesaṃ pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ nābbhaññāsiṃ, neva tāvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya ‘anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddho’ti paccaññāsiṃ.
sn48.21:1.4.eng: As long as I didn’t truly understand these five faculties’ gratification, drawback, and escape, I didn’t announce my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.

sn48.21:1.5.pli: Yato ca khvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imesaṃ pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ, athāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya ‘anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddho’ti paccaññāsiṃ.
sn48.21:1.5.eng: But when I did truly understand these five faculties’ gratification, drawback, and escape, I announced my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.

sn48.21:1.6.eng: Knowledge and vision arose in me:

sn48.21:1.7.pli: ‘akuppā me vimutti, ayamantimā jāti, natthi dāni punabbhavo’”ti.
sn48.21:1.7.eng: ‘My freedom is unshakable; this is my last rebirth; now there’ll be no more future lives.’”

sn48.22:1.3.eng: The faculties of femininity, masculinity, and life.
